member.summary: Mouse state, set every frame in the Update method.

member.name: F:Nine.XnaInputSource.keyboardState
member.summary: Keyboard state, set every frame in the Update method. Note: KeyboardState is a class and not a struct, we have to initialize it here, else we might run into trouble when accessing any keyboardState data before BaseGame.Update() is called. We can also NOT use the last state because every time we call Keyboard.GetState() the old state is useless (see XNA help for more information, section Input). We store our own array of keys from the last frame for comparing stuff.

member.name: F:Nine.XnaInputSource.keysPressedLastFrame
member.summary: Keys pressed last frame, for comparison if a key was just pressed.

member.name: F:Nine.XnaInputSource.mouseWheelDelta
member.summary: Mouse wheel delta this frame. XNA does report only the total scroll value, but we usually need the current delta!

member.summary: Defines the behavior of the last ending keyframe.
member.remarks: The difference between these behaviors won't be noticeable unless the KeyframeAnimation is really slow.

member.name: F:Nine.Animations.KeyframeEnding.Clamp
member.summary: The animation will wait for the last frame to finish but won't blend the last frame with the first frame. Specify this when your animation isn't looped.

member.name: F:Nine.Animations.KeyframeEnding.Wrap
member.summary: The animation will blend between the last keyframe and the first keyframe. Specify this when the animation is looped and the first frame doesn't equal to the last frame.

member.name: F:Nine.Animations.KeyframeEnding.Discard
member.summary: The animation will stop immediately when it reaches the last frame, so the ending frame has no duration. Specify this when the animation is looped and the first frame is identical to the last frame.

member.name: T:Nine.Input
member.summary: A basic class that pushes input events to the consumer.
member.remarks:
Before you create Input object, make sure a valid InputComponent object is created.
You can create as many Input instances any where without worrying much about performance and memory leak.
However, you need to explicitly keep an reference on Input instances, otherwise the garbage collector may collect the instance and no events will be raised after that.
